newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SM SUMMIT DENIES SOFTWARE PIRACY CHARGES.
newsitem.headline: SM SUMMIT DENIES SOFTWARE PIRACY CHARGES.

text.p: Compact disc-maker SM Summit Holdings denied on Wednesday it was engaged in software piracy as had been charged by Microsoft and two other U.S. companies.
The company said in a statement it was fully aware of its obligations under the law.
"It is inconceivable, therefore, that the company would be engaged in software piracy in the manner as alleged by BSA," it said referring to the Business Software Alliance industry watchdog.
"The company will strenuously defend (itself against) any and all allegations of impropriety in this matter," it said.
The company said it had a procedure to ensure that there would not be any piracy of cassette tapes or compact discs.
It said it had never experienced any piracy problems with its audio or its CD-ROM businesses.
"Before the company process(es) any order it will always verify if the content contain(s) pirated software," it said.
SM Summit said it produced discs for contract customers, packaging the customers' material, but it obtained a guarantee from these customers that the material was not pirated.

"In addition, the company obtains from the customer a warranty and an indemnity that the material supplied by the customer to the company would not result in the infringement of intellectual property rights of third parties," it said.
